issue.title: PQ-hybrid key exchange encodings
issue.body:
Hi, 

As we are interop testing we found an issue in how OQS OpenSSH encodes the exchanged keys.

The way it works today in OQS OpenSSH, the shared secret is `K = HASH((PQ shared key) || (ECDH shared key))`
- The ```PQ shared key``` is encoded as raw data (`byte` in the SSH RFC https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4251#section-5 ). 
- The ```ECDH shared key``` is encoded as ```mpint``` as per the SSH RFC https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4251#section-5 . That is probably because that it was done previously as per RFC4253 and because the exchanged ECDH shared key is a big integer and `K` ended up being `mpint`. 
- `K = HASH((PQ shared key) || (ECDH shared key))` is used as a `byte` array for deriving encryption keys for SSH https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh/blob/92c59cf2f25fb32b21ce8d7b11a8af246ea17062/kexoqsecdh.c#L94 

The PQ SSH draft is currently a little ambiguous on this, and I will update it to be more prescriptive, but we want to make a suggestion here to make sure we are all implementers on the same page: 

Both ```PQ shared key``` and ```ECDH shared key``` would rather be a simple `byte` array padded to the nearest byte boundary. Previously `mpint` worked because ```ECDH shared key``` was going directly into `K`, but that is not the case any more. ```PQ shared key``` and ```ECDH shared key``` go into a hash, so they ought to be raw data, fixed-length, simple `byte` array padded to the nearest byte boundary. Using `mpint` for one shared key and raw data for the other is inconsistent and `mpint` adds some predictability into the content of the hash input buffer. 

Btw, that is what OpenSSH does with its X25519+SNTRU PQ-hybrid key exchange method. 

@dstebila , @baentsch , @christianpaquin , what do you think?

comment.body:
Gotcha. Done. I just added in  https://github.com/csosto-pk/pq-ssh/blob/master/draft-kampanakis-ssh-pq-ke.txt the method names 
- ```ecdh-nistp256-kyber-512r3-sha256-d00@openquantumsafe.org``` (OQS OpenSSH supports this) 
- ```ecdh-nistp384-kyber-768r3-sha384-d00@openquantumsafe.org``` (OQS OpenSSH supports this) 
- ```ecdh-nistp521-kyber-1024r3-sha512-d00@openquantumsafe.org``` (OQS OpenSSH supports this) 
- ```x25519-kyber-512r3-sha256-d00@amazon.com``` (OQS OpenSSH does NOT support this) 

Please note the name changes.
-  I put the ```d00``` at the end so it is more pronounced. 
- I used ```r3``` since we are still using the Kyber spec implementation in from NIST's Round 3. 
- I did not use a dash ```-``` for ```r3```. I did that so that the round revision is attached to Kyber in the name to make it clearer.

We will code up our side to these now. If you violently object to any of these names, please let me know.

issue.title: Enable CA functionality
issue.body:
Fixes #115 (somewhat a workaround for ["semi-documented" OpenSSL behaviour regarding mandatory and default digest](https://github.com/openssl/openssl/blob/d0a3b9d1eb1fc510ec3447b44803bbf5520a0c47/apps/ca.c#L810)).

- Adds CA testing (contribution by @Dechen2333) 
- Makes test script more robust with absolute paths

comment.body: This needs to land for IETF hackathon use (enabling use of ca and ocsp functionality). Will need to be revised when https://github.com/openssl/openssl/issues/20428 finally lands.

issue.title: RISC-V support
issue.body:
Hello,

I am porting various packages to riscv64 platform. I saw comments on compilation in CMakeLists.txt:

```
Compilation on an unsupported processor should only be used for testing, as it may result an insecure configuration, for example due to variable-time instructions leaking secret information.
```

Is there anything we need to do, like auditing RISC-V processors, in order to have them supported?

comment.body:
Hello -- thanks very much for your interest to help move this project forward!

> Is there anything we need to do, like auditing RISC-V processors, in order to have them supported?

The best would be an addition of such processors to a CI environment in which this support could be "proven" (by successfully running the (self)tests). We're open to any suggestions as to which such CI system to use for this.

issue.title: Update HQC.
issue.body: The implementation taken from PQClean [is based on the 2020-10-01 specification](https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean/blob/master/crypto_kem/hqc-rmrs-128/META.yml#L25), and the latest version is [2021/06/06](https://pqc-hqc.org/implementation.html). The latest specification uses KECCAK for domain separation and randomness.

comment.body: HQC has a constant-time security problem: https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean/issues/482

issue.title: Update HQC.
issue.body: The implementation taken from PQClean [is based on the 2020-10-01 specification](https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean/blob/master/crypto_kem/hqc-rmrs-128/META.yml#L25), and the latest version is [2021/06/06](https://pqc-hqc.org/implementation.html). The latest specification uses KECCAK for domain separation and randomness.

comment.body: Ah, and https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/issues/995 was already known as well.

issue.title: Update HQC.
issue.body: The implementation taken from PQClean [is based on the 2020-10-01 specification](https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean/blob/master/crypto_kem/hqc-rmrs-128/META.yml#L25), and the latest version is [2021/06/06](https://pqc-hqc.org/implementation.html). The latest specification uses KECCAK for domain separation and randomness.

comment.body:
Note that the `Optimized_Implementation` and the `Additional_Implementation` in the [round 4 submission](https://csrc.nist.gov/csrc/media/Projects/post-quantum-cryptography/documents/round-4/submissions/HQC-Round4.zip) follow a different spec. The latter is made to be compatible with the hardware implementation, but e.g. still uses the timing side-channel vulnerable rejection sampling.

A `clean` implementation that is also constant-time therefore cannot (easily) be based on the `Additional_Implementation`.

issue.body:
Hi, 

As we are interop testing we found an issue in how OQS OpenSSH encodes the exchanged keys.

The way it works today in OQS OpenSSH, the shared secret is `K = HASH((PQ shared key) || (ECDH shared key))`
- The ```PQ shared key``` is encoded as raw data (`byte` in the SSH RFC https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4251#section-5 ). 
- The ```ECDH shared key``` is encoded as ```mpint``` as per the SSH RFC https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4251#section-5 . That is probably because that it was done previously as per RFC4253 and because the exchanged ECDH shared key is a big integer and `K` ended up being `mpint`. 
- `K = HASH((PQ shared key) || (ECDH shared key))` is used as a `byte` array for deriving encryption keys for SSH https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh/blob/92c59cf2f25fb32b21ce8d7b11a8af246ea17062/kexoqsecdh.c#L94

Using `mpint` for one shared key and raw data for the other is inconsistent and `mpint` adds some predictability into the content of the hash input buffer.

@dstebila , @baentsch , @christianpaquin , what do you think?

issue.title: Version numbering
issue.body:
We're currently using the liboqs version numbering scheme, which does make it clear which version we're bundling. However, that also means that we can't really release patch versions. This is sometimes a problem: #189 

One possibility would be to do the following: Release `0.7.2` as `7.2.0` so that we can actually issue patch releases.

comment.body:
What do you think about basically moving OQS versioning one position to the left? ie. `0.7.2` -> `7.2.0`?

Another option could be to do `0.7.2` -> `0.72.0` now that I think of it. I kinda like that as it preserves the "pointoh-ness" of the release.

issue.title: Version numbering
issue.body:
We're currently using the liboqs version numbering scheme, which does make it clear which version we're bundling. However, that also means that we can't really release patch versions. This is sometimes a problem: #189 

One possibility would be to do the following: Release `0.7.2` as `7.2.0` so that we can actually issue patch releases.

comment.body: Oooh, I like 0.7.200.  I had also thought of the 7.2.0 idea but it seemed too drastic, and would lose the oomph of a 1.0 when it happens.

comment.body:
> We will code up our side to these now.

Does this mean you'll be updating this PR as well, or do we need to do that?

issue.title: Remove Kyber90s and Dilithium-AES variants
issue.body: [NIST has said](https://csrc.nist.gov/csrc/media/Presentations/2022/nist-pqc-looking-into-the-future/images-media/session-1-moody-looking-into-future-pqc2022.pdf) they have no intention to standardize these variants. I checked with Peter Schwabe and he's not aware of any plans to keep them alive elsewhere.

comment.body: As suggested by @baentsch, easiest if we save doing this until we are also updating other algorithms, so as to only have to do one downstream update.

comment.body:
> > We will code up our side to these now.
> 
> Does this mean you'll be updating this PR as well, or do we need to do that?

Hmm, let me cut you a new PR that updates the method names in ```kex.h```. I will paste the PR name here.
